projectDesc.p: Originally prepared for the purpose of amplifying the ideas that Black Twitter users have on the blockbuster film Black Panther which was released on Feburary 16, 2018.

This thread was encoded because it exemplifies the celebration of blackness. Black Twitter users are excited about the celebration of Black, specifically African culture and tradtions that were depicted in the Black Panther movie. These people used Twitter as a digital space to discuss aspects of their culture.

samplingDecl.p: Only one or two pictures were encoded from each tweet in the thread using the appropriate TEI tags. This is due to the fact that only one picture showing an aspect of African culture decpicted in Black Panther along with one picture showing African culture in the real world is suffiecent enough to develop an understanding about what the author is describing in each tweet.

normalization.p: African American vernacular that was used in some of the tweets has been retained in order to normalize it as a viable language.

Hashtags (#Wakanda and #BlackPanther) have been retained at the end of each tweet to emphasize the goal of the author who wrote this tweet thread. The author hoped to reach a wide range of people so that her work could be viewed by many in order to encourage conversation about African culture, tribes, and traditions depicted in Black Panther.

The emojis used in the tweet thread to show the flag of the African country that some of the characters come from has been omitted. This was done because we believe that it is not important to the actual content or importance of the text. Also, TEI has very little tags that allow for emojis to be encoded.

div.p: Thread on African tribes/cultures featured in #BlackPanther. #Wakanda
41,132 Retweets 55,784 Likes

Mursi and Surma Lip Plates. Lip plates or disks are a form of ceremonial body modification. While many cultures use them they're best known by the Surma and Mursi tribes in Ethiopia. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This figure depicts characters of a specific tribe in the movie Black Panther. The tribe leader wears a Surma or Mursi lip plate as described by the author of this tweet thread.
This picture is of a women who belongs to an actual Surma or Mursi tribe in Ethiopia. She wears a lip plate which is simliar to the tribe leader character in the movie.

div.p: Zulu headdress. Queen Ramonda wears a distinct headdress. It's reminiscent of the reed Zulu flared hats or "Isicholos." The Zulu headdresses are traditionally worn by married women for ceremonial celebrations.

figure.figDesc: This picture is a collage of four different pictures. Two of the pictures show the character, Queen Romonda, wearing a traditional Zulu headdress in the film. The other two pictures show two real life women who wear the "Isicholos".

div.p: Many of the costumes have unique and futuristic ornamentation and details. These were made by emulating styles of the Masai people Maasai people. The Maasai people of East Africa live in southern Kenya and northern Tanzania. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This picture depicts the "futuristic" costumes worn by some of the characters in the movie.
This picture is of a group of actual Maasai people. It can be seen that the costumes used in the film were influenced by the tradtional attire of this group of people.

div.p: Igbo Mask. In one scene Erik Killmonger wears a mask. The masks, known as Mgbedike, are distinguished by the large size and bold masculine features. They are used in Igbo rituals and are designed to contrast the female dancers with their more feminine beauty. #BlackPanther

figure.figDesc: This picture shows the character, Erik Killmonger, wearing a tradtional Igbo Mask.
This picure shows a side-by-side of Erik Killmonger wearing an Igbo mask in the movie and an actual Igbo mask that has been displayed in what looks like a museuem.

div.p: Basotho Blanket. In several scenes, W'Kabi (Daniel Kaluuya) and others are shown wearing Basotho blankets around their necks. Though the blankets are originally from the Lesotho people the designs are synonymous with the Sesotho people. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This picture is a collage made up of three different pictures. one of the pictures shows the character, W'Kabi, wearing an article of clothing that is simliar to a Basotho blanket. The other two photos show two other men who wear the Basotho blanket in the real world.

div.p: Ndebele Neck Rings. Shuri and the Dora Milaje have outfits with a prominent collar. The South Ndebele peoples of Zimbabwe and South Africa wear neck rings as part of their traditional dress and as a sign of wealth and status. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This photo is of the character, Dora Milaje, wearing a costume with a "prominent collar" which is similar to the tradtitonal Ndebele neck rings.
This photo is of a women wearing tradtional Ndebele neck rings.

div.p: Many of the costumes have a distinctive red earthy tone. This was done by studying the colors used by the Himba people of north-western North-Western Namibia. Himba people are known for applying a red ochre paste, known as "otjize", to their skin and hair. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This collage shows all three of the pictures used by the author to depict the Himba people of North-Western Namibia. One picture shows a tribe leader in the film who has applied red ochre paste like the two women in the other two photos who use "otjize" on their skin and hair in real life.

div.p: Forest Whittaker plays shaman Zuri who's the spiritual leader of Wakanda. He wears ornate flowing robes known as an Agbada. It's one of the names for a flowing wide-sleeved robe worn by men/women in much of West Africa ,and North Africa. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This image is of the character, shaman Zuri, along with another character in the film. They both wear costumes that resemble traditional Agbada.

div.p: There was a lot of inspiration taken from the Dogonpeople. They live in the central plateau region of Mali, in West Africa. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is an image of three Dogon men in their ceremonial attire, which influenced many of Black Panther costumes.

div.p: Tuaregscarfs. Several characters in the film wear large scarves covering their head and face. These are similar to the ones worn by the Tuareg people. The Tuareg people inhabit an area in North and West Africa. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is a collage of all four of the pictures that they author used to match her description of the Tuareg scarf. One of the pictures is a screenshoot from the Black Panther movie which contains characters wearing Tuareg scarfs. The other three pictures show men and women in real life wearing the Tuareg scarf.

div.p: Other tribes of sartorial inspiration were the Turkana people in Kenya. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This picture is of three women from the Turkana tribe in Kenya wearing large beaded neck rings which inspired the creation of some of the costumes in the film.

div.p: The language spoken in #Wakanda is Xhosa, a language spoken by over 19 million people in Southern Africa.

figure.figDesc: This is a map of South Africa that has shaded percentages of how many people speak the Xhosa language, the primary language used by African characters in the film

div.p: Did y'all catch when our sis Lupitabegins the film fighting for enslaved girls in Nigeria. Lupita learned to speak Hausa for certain scenes in the film. She also trained in judo, jujitsu, silat and Filipino martial arts.

div.p: T'Challa's Kente scarf. Kente, known as nwentom in Akan, is a type of silk and cotton fabric made of interwoven cloth strips and is native to the Akan people of Ghana.#BlackPanther #Wakanda

div.p: The Great Rift Valley. Scientists have estimated that the Great Rift Valley found in Kenya was formed over 20 million years ago when the Earth's crust began to split. #BlackPanther #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is a picture of a man standing on a cliff overlooking the Great Rift Valley in Kenya. This valley shows similarities to the valley of Wakanda in the film.

This is a picture is taken from the Black Panther poster. The author has cut the bottom of the poster off to emphasize the character, Black Panther, standing on the Black Panther shaped cliff of Wakanda. This cliff and the view from it resemble the Great Rift Valley of Kenya.

div.p: Tribal make-up is practiced in many African tribes.The make-up, often in the form of face paint, is used for many different reasons and can signify many different things such as hunting, religious and traditional reasons, military purposes or to scare an enemy. #BlackPanther

figure.figDesc: This is an image of Letitia Wright as the charcter Shuri, who wears paint on her face, very simliar to tribal make-up used by African tribes.

div.p: #BlackPanther was totally a Afrocentric natural hair movie. Inspiration came from this collection of black hairstyles shot by the Nigerian photographer J.D. ’Okhai Ojeikere. #Wakanda

figure.figDesc: This is a picture of girl with a natural Black hairstyle which was included in the collection of photos by the Nigerian photographer J. D. ’Okhai Ojeikere.
